intro: Conyza bidentata, commonly known as the two-toothed cudweed, is an annual herbaceous plant native to temperate regions of the Northern Hemisphere. It belongs to the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads that consist of both ray and disk flowers. The plant typically grows to a height of 20–60 cm, with opposite, lance-shaped leaves that have serrated edges. Its small yellow flowers bloom in the summer, and the plant produces numerous small, wind-dispersed seeds. Conyza bidentata is often found in disturbed soils, such as roadsides and fields, and is considered a weed in agricultural settings.
